Sentence: For the Sadducees say that there is no resurrection, neither angel, nor spirit: but the Pharisees confess both.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And there arose a great cry: and the scribes [that were] of the Pharisees’ part arose, and strove, saying, We find no evil in this man: but if a spirit or an angel hath spoken to him, let us not fight against God.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when there arose a great dissension, the chief captain, fearing lest Paul should have been pulled in pieces of them, commanded the soldiers to go down, and to take him by force from among them, and to bring [him] into the castle.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And the night following the Lord stood by him, and said, Be of good cheer, Paul: for as thou hast testified of me in Jerusalem, so must thou bear witness also at Rome.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when it was day, certain of the Jews banded together, and bound themselves under a curse, saying that they would neither eat nor drink till they had killed Paul.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And they were more than forty which had made this conspiracy.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And they came to the chief priests and elders, and said, We have bound ourselves under a great curse, that we will eat nothing until we have slain Paul.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Now therefore ye with the council signify to the chief captain that he bring him down unto you to morrow, as though ye would inquire something more perfectly concerning him: and we, or ever he come near, are ready to kill him.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when Paul’s sister’s son heard of their lying in wait, he went and entered into the castle, and told Paul.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Then Paul called one of the centurions unto [him], and said, Bring this young man unto the chief captain: for he hath a certain thing to tell him.

Author: Luke
Sentence: So he took him, and brought [him] to the chief captain, and said, Paul the prisoner called me unto [him], and prayed me to bring this young man unto thee, who hath something to say unto thee.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Then the chief captain took him by the hand, and went [with him] aside privately, and asked [him], What is that thou hast to tell me?

Author: Luke
Sentence: And he said, The Jews have agreed to desire thee that thou wouldest bring down Paul to morrow into the council, as though they would inquire somewhat of him more perfectly.

Author: Luke
Sentence: But do not thou yield unto them: for there lie in wait for him of them more than forty men, which have bound themselves with an oath, that they will neither eat nor drink till they have killed him: and now are they ready, looking for a promise from thee.

Author: Luke
Sentence: So the chief captain [then] let the young man depart, and charged [him, See thou] tell no man that thou hast shewed these things to me.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And he called unto [him] two centurions, saying, Make ready two hundred soldiers to go to Caesarea, and horsemen threescore and ten, and spearmen two hundred, at the third hour of the night;

Author: Luke
Sentence: And provide [them] beasts, that they may set Paul on, and bring [him] safe unto Felix the governor.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And he wrote a letter after this manner:

Author: Luke
Sentence: Claudius Lysias unto the most excellent governor Felix [sendeth] greeting.

Author: Luke
Sentence: This man was taken of the Jews, and should have been killed of them: then came I with an army, and rescued him, having understood that he was a Roman.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when I would have known the cause wherefore they accused him, I brought him forth into their council:

Author: Luke
Sentence: Whom I perceived to be accused of questions of their law, but to have nothing laid to his charge worthy of death or of bonds.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when it was told me how that the Jews laid wait for the man, I sent straightway to thee, and gave commandment to his accusers also to say before thee what [they had] against him.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Farewell.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Then the soldiers, as it was commanded them, took Paul, and brought [him] by night to Antipatris.

Author: Luke
Sentence: On the morrow they left the horsemen to go with him, and returned to the castle:

Author: Luke
Sentence: Who, when they came to Caesarea, and delivered the epistle to the governor, presented Paul also before him.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when the governor had read [the letter], he asked of what province he was.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when he understood that [he was] of Cilicia;

Author: Luke
Sentence: I will hear thee, said he, when thine accusers are also come.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And he commanded him to be kept in Herod’s judgment hall.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And after five days Ananias the high priest descended with the elders, and [with] a certain orator [named] Tertullus, who informed the governor against Paul.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when he was called forth, Tertullus began to accuse [him], saying, Seeing that by thee we enjoy great quietness, and that very worthy deeds are done unto this nation by thy providence,

Author: Luke
Sentence: We accept [it] always, and in all places, most noble Felix, with all thankfulness.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Notwithstanding, that I be not further tedious unto thee, I pray thee that thou wouldest hear us of thy clemency a few words.

Author: Luke
Sentence: For we have found this man [a] pestilent [fellow], and a mover of sedition among all the Jews throughout the world, and a ringleader of the sect of the Nazarenes:

Author: Luke
Sentence: Who also hath gone about to profane the temple: whom we took, and would have judged according to our law.

Author: Luke
Sentence: But the chief captain Lysias came [upon us], and with great violence took [him] away out of our hands,

Author: Luke
Sentence: Commanding his accusers to come unto thee: by examining of whom thyself mayest take knowledge of all these things, whereof we accuse him.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And the Jews also assented, saying that these things were so.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Then Paul, after that the governor had beckoned unto him to speak, answered, Forasmuch as I know that thou hast been of many years a judge unto this nation, I do the more cheerfully answer for myself:

Author: Luke
Sentence: Because that thou mayest understand, that there are yet but twelve days since I went up to Jerusalem for to worship.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And they neither found me in the temple disputing with any man, neither raising up the people, neither in the synagogues, nor in the city:

Author: Luke
Sentence: Neither can they prove the things whereof they now accuse me.

Author: Luke
Sentence: But this I confess unto thee, that after the way which they call heresy, so worship I the God of my fathers, believing all things which are written in the law and in the prophets:

Author: Luke
Sentence: And have hope toward God, which they themselves also allow, that there shall be a resurrection of the dead, both of the just and unjust.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And herein do I exercise myself, to have always a conscience void of offence toward God, and [toward] men.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Now after many years I came to bring alms to my nation, and offerings.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Whereupon certain Jews from Asia found me purified in the temple, neither with multitude, nor with tumult.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Who ought to have been here before thee, and object, if they had ought against me.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Or else let these same [here] say, if they have found any evil doing in me, while I stood before the council,

Author: Luke
Sentence: Except it be for this one voice, that I cried standing among them, Touching the resurrection of the dead I am called in question by you this day.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when Felix heard these things, having more perfect knowledge of [that] way, he deferred them, and said, When Lysias the chief captain shall come down, I will know the uttermost of your matter.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And he commanded a centurion to keep Paul, and to let [him] have liberty, and that he should forbid none of his acquaintance to minister or come unto him.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And after certain days, when Felix came with his wife Drusilla, which was a Jewess, he sent for Paul, and heard him concerning the faith in Christ.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And as he reasoned of righteousness, temperance, and judgment to come, Felix trembled, and answered, Go thy way for this time; when I have a convenient season, I will call for thee.

Author: Luke
Sentence: He hoped also that money should have been given him of Paul, that he might loose him: wherefore he sent for him the oftener, and communed with him.

Author: Luke
Sentence: But after two years Porcius Festus came into Felix’ room: and Felix, willing to shew the Jews a pleasure, left Paul bound.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Now when Festus was come into the province, after three days he ascended from Caesarea to Jerusalem.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Then the high priest and the chief of the Jews informed him against Paul, and besought him,

Author: Luke
Sentence: And desired favour against him, that he would send for him to Jerusalem, laying wait in the way to kill him.

Author: Luke
Sentence: But Festus answered, that Paul should be kept at Caesarea, and that he himself would depart shortly [thither].

Author: Luke
Sentence: Let them therefore, said he, which among you are able, go down with [me], and accuse this man, if there be any wickedness in him.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when he had tarried among them more than ten days, he went down unto Caesarea; and the next day sitting on the judgment seat commanded Paul to be brought.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when he was come, the Jews which came down from Jerusalem stood round about, and laid many and grievous complaints against Paul, which they could not prove.

Author: Luke
Sentence: While he answered for himself, Neither against the law of the Jews, neither against the temple, nor yet against Caesar, have I offended any thing at all.

Author: Luke
Sentence: But Festus, willing to do the Jews a pleasure, answered Paul, and said, Wilt thou go up to Jerusalem, and there be judged of these things before me?

Author: Luke
Sentence: Then said Paul, I stand at Caesar’s judgment seat, where I ought to be judged: to the Jews have I done no wrong, as thou very well knowest.

Author: Luke
Sentence: For if I be an offender, or have committed any thing worthy of death, I refuse not to die: but if there be none of these things whereof these accuse me, no man may deliver me unto them.

Author: Luke
Sentence: I appeal unto Caesar.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Then Festus, when he had conferred with the council, answered, Hast thou appealed unto Caesar?

Author: Luke
Sentence: unto Caesar shalt thou go.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And after certain days king Agrippa and Bernice came unto Caesarea to salute Festus.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when they had been there many days, Festus declared Paul’s cause unto the king, saying, There is a certain man left in bonds by Felix:

Author: Luke
Sentence: About whom, when I was at Jerusalem, the chief priests and the elders of the Jews informed [me], desiring [to have] judgment against him.

Author: Luke
Sentence: To whom I answered, It is not the manner of the Romans to deliver any man to die, before that he which is accused have the accusers face to face, and have licence to answer for himself concerning the crime laid against him.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Therefore, when they were come hither, without any delay on the morrow I sat on the judgment seat, and commanded the man to be brought forth.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Against whom when the accusers stood up, they brought none accusation of such things as I supposed:

Author: Luke
Sentence: But had certain questions against him of their own superstition, and of one Jesus, which was dead, whom Paul affirmed to be alive.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And because I doubted of such manner of questions, I asked [him] whether he would go to Jerusalem, and there be judged of these matters.

Author: Luke
Sentence: But when Paul had appealed to be reserved unto the hearing of Augustus, I commanded him to be kept till I might send him to Caesar.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Then Agrippa said unto Festus, I would also hear the man myself.

Author: Luke
Sentence: To morrow, said he, thou shalt hear him.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And on the morrow, when Agrippa was come, and Bernice, with great pomp, and was entered into the place of hearing, with the chief captains, and principal men of the city, at Festus’ commandment Paul was brought forth.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And Festus said, King Agrippa, and all men which are here present with us, ye see this man, about whom all the multitude of the Jews have dealt with me, both at Jerusalem, and [also] here, crying that he ought not to live any longer.

Author: Luke
Sentence: But when I found that he had committed nothing worthy of death, and that he himself hath appealed to Augustus, I have determined to send him.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Of whom I have no certain thing to write unto my lord.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Wherefore I have brought him forth before you, and specially before thee, O king Agrippa, that, after examination had, I might have somewhat to write.

Author: Luke
Sentence: For it seemeth to me unreasonable to send a prisoner, and not withal to signify the crimes [laid] against him.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Then Agrippa said unto Paul, Thou art permitted to speak for thyself.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Then Paul stretched forth the hand, and answered for himself:

Author: Luke
Sentence: I think myself happy, king Agrippa, because I shall answer for myself this day before thee touching all the things whereof I am accused of the Jews:

Author: Luke
Sentence: Especially [because I know] thee to be expert in all customs and questions which are among the Jews: wherefore I beseech thee to hear me patiently.

Author: Luke
Sentence: My manner of life from my youth, which was at the first among mine own nation at Jerusalem, know all the Jews;

Author: Luke
Sentence: Which knew me from the beginning, if they would testify, that after the most straitest sect of our religion I lived a Pharisee.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And now I stand and am judged for the hope of the promise made of God unto our fathers:

Author: Luke
Sentence: Unto which [promise] our twelve tribes, instantly serving [God] day and night, hope to come.

Author: Luke
Sentence: For which hope’s sake, king Agrippa, I am accused of the Jews.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Why should it be thought a thing incredible with you, that God should raise the dead?

Author: Luke
Sentence: I verily thought with myself, that I ought to do many things contrary to the name of Jesus of Nazareth.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Which thing I also did in Jerusalem: and many of the saints did I shut up in prison, having received authority from the chief priests; and when they were put to death, I gave my voice against [them].

Author: Luke
Sentence: And I punished them oft in every synagogue, and compelled [them] to blaspheme; and being exceedingly mad against them, I persecuted [them] even unto strange cities.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Whereupon as I went to Damascus with authority and commission from the chief priests,

Author: Luke
Sentence: At midday, O king, I saw in the way a light from heaven, above the brightness of the sun, shining round about me and them which journeyed with me.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when we were all fallen to the earth, I heard a voice speaking unto me, and saying in the Hebrew tongue, Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?

Author: Luke
Sentence: [it is] hard for thee to kick against the pricks.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And I said, Who art thou, Lord?

Author: Luke
Sentence: And he said, I am Jesus whom thou persecutest.

Author: Luke
Sentence: But rise, and stand upon thy feet: for I have appeared unto thee for this purpose, to make thee a minister and a witness both of these things which thou hast seen, and of those things in the which I will appear unto thee;

Author: Luke
Sentence: Delivering thee from the people, and [from] the Gentiles, unto whom now I send thee,

Author: Luke
Sentence: To open their eyes, [and] to turn [them] from darkness to light, and [from] the power of Satan unto God, that they may receive forgiveness of sins, and inheritance among them which are sanctified by faith that is in me.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Whereupon, O king Agrippa, I was not disobedient unto the heavenly vision:

Author: Luke
Sentence: But shewed first unto them of Damascus, and at Jerusalem, and throughout all the coasts of Judaea, and [then] to the Gentiles, that they should repent and turn to God, and do works meet for repentance.

Author: Luke
Sentence: For these causes the Jews caught me in the temple, and went about to kill [me].

Author: Luke
Sentence: Having therefore obtained help of God, I continue unto this day, witnessing both to small and great, saying none other things than those which the prophets and Moses did say should come:

Author: Luke
Sentence: That Christ should suffer, [and] that he should be the first that should rise from the dead, and should shew light unto the people, and to the Gentiles.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And as he thus spake for himself, Festus said with a loud voice, Paul, thou art beside thyself; much learning doth make thee mad.

Author: Luke
Sentence: But he said, I am not mad, most noble Festus; but speak forth the words of truth and soberness.

Author: Luke
Sentence: For the king knoweth of these things, before whom also I speak freely: for I am persuaded that none of these things are hidden from him; for this thing was not done in a corner.

Author: Luke
Sentence: King Agrippa, believest thou the prophets?

Author: Luke
Sentence: I know that thou believest.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Then Agrippa said unto Paul, Almost thou persuadest me to be a Christian.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And Paul said, I would to God, that not only thou, but also all that hear me this day, were both almost, and altogether such as I am, except these bonds.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when he had thus spoken, the king rose up, and the governor, and Bernice, and they that sat with them:

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when they were gone aside, they talked between themselves, saying, This man doeth nothing worthy of death or of bonds.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Then said Agrippa unto Festus, This man might have been set at liberty, if he had not appealed unto Caesar.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when it was determined that we should sail into Italy, they delivered Paul and certain other prisoners unto [one] named Julius, a centurion of Augustus’ band.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And entering into a ship of Adramyttium, we launched, meaning to sail by the coasts of Asia; [one] Aristarchus, a Macedonian of Thessalonica, being with us.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And the next [day] we touched at Sidon.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And Julius courteously entreated Paul, and gave [him] liberty to go unto his friends to refresh himself.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when we had launched from thence, we sailed under Cyprus, because the winds were contrary.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when we had sailed over the sea of Cilicia and Pamphylia, we came to Myra, [a city] of Lycia.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And there the centurion found a ship of Alexandria sailing into Italy; and he put us therein.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when we had sailed slowly many days, and scarce were come over against Cnidus, the wind not suffering us, we sailed under Crete, over against Salmone;

Author: Luke
Sentence: And, hardly passing it, came unto a place which is called The fair havens; nigh whereunto was the city [of] Lasea.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Now when much time was spent, and when sailing was now dangerous, because the fast was now already past, Paul admonished [them],

Author: Luke
Sentence: And said unto them, Sirs, I perceive that this voyage will be with hurt and much damage, not only of the lading and ship, but also of our lives.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Nevertheless the centurion believed the master and the owner of the ship, more than those things which were spoken by Paul.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And because the haven was not commodious to winter in, the more part advised to depart thence also, if by any means they might attain to Phenice, [and there] to winter; [which is] an haven of Crete, and lieth toward the south west and north west.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when the south wind blew softly, supposing that they had obtained [their] purpose, loosing [thence], they sailed close by Crete.

Author: Luke
Sentence: But not long after there arose against it a tempestuous wind, called Euroclydon.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when the ship was caught, and could not bear up into the wind, we let [her] drive.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And running under a certain island which is called Clauda, we had much work to come by the boat:

Author: Luke
Sentence: Which when they had taken up, they used helps, undergirding the ship; and, fearing lest they should fall into the quicksands, strake sail, and so were driven.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And we being exceedingly tossed with a tempest, the next [day] they lightened the ship;

Author: Luke
Sentence: And the third [day] we cast out with our own hands the tackling of the ship.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when neither sun nor stars in many days appeared, and no small tempest lay on [us], all hope that we should be saved was then taken away.

Author: Luke
Sentence: But after long abstinence Paul stood forth in the midst of them, and said, Sirs, ye should have hearkened unto me, and not have loosed from Crete, and to have gained this harm and loss.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And now I exhort you to be of good cheer: for there shall be no loss of [any man’s] life among you, but of the ship.

Author: Luke
Sentence: For there stood by me this night the angel of God, whose I am, and whom I serve,

Author: Luke
Sentence: Saying, Fear not, Paul; thou must be brought before Caesar: and, lo, God hath given thee all them that sail with thee.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Wherefore, sirs, be of good cheer: for I believe God, that it shall be even as it was told me.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Howbeit we must be cast upon a certain island.

Author: Luke
Sentence: But when the fourteenth night was come, as we were driven up and down in Adria, about midnight the shipmen deemed that they drew near to some country;

Author: Luke
Sentence: And sounded, and found [it] twenty fathoms: and when they had gone a little further, they sounded again, and found [it] fifteen fathoms.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Then fearing lest we should have fallen upon rocks, they cast four anchors out of the stern, and wished for the day.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And as the shipmen were about to flee out of the ship, when they had let down the boat into the sea, under colour as though they would have cast anchors out of the foreship,

Author: Luke
Sentence: Paul said to the centurion and to the soldiers, Except these abide in the ship, ye cannot be saved.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Then the soldiers cut off the ropes of the boat, and let her fall off.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And while the day was coming on, Paul besought [them] all to take meat, saying, This day is the fourteenth day that ye have tarried and continued fasting, having taken nothing.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Wherefore I pray you to take [some] meat: for this is for your health: for there shall not an hair fall from the head of any of you.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when he had thus spoken, he took bread, and gave thanks to God in presence of them all: and when he had broken [it], he began to eat.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Then were they all of good cheer, and they also took [some] meat.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And we were in all in the ship two hundred threescore and sixteen souls.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when they had eaten enough, they lightened the ship, and cast out the wheat into the sea.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when it was day, they knew not the land: but they discovered a certain creek with a shore, into the which they were minded, if it were possible, to thrust in the ship.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when they had taken up the anchors, they committed [themselves] unto the sea, and loosed the rudder bands, and hoised up the mainsail to the wind, and made toward shore.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And falling into a place where two seas met, they ran the ship aground; and the forepart stuck fast, and remained unmoveable, but the hinder part was broken with the violence of the waves.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And the soldiers’ counsel was to kill the prisoners, lest any of them should swim out, and escape.

Author: Luke
Sentence: But the centurion, willing to save Paul, kept them from [their] purpose; and commanded that they which could swim should cast [themselves] first [into the sea], and get to land:

Author: Luke
Sentence: And the rest, some on boards, and some on [broken pieces] of the ship.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And so it came to pass, that they escaped all safe to land.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when they were escaped, then they knew that the island was called Melita.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And the barbarous people shewed us no little kindness: for they kindled a fire, and received us every one, because of the present rain, and because of the cold.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when Paul had gathered a bundle of sticks, and laid [them] on the fire, there came a viper out of the heat, and fastened on his hand.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when the barbarians saw the [venomous] beast hang on his hand, they said among themselves, No doubt this man is a murderer, whom, though he hath escaped the sea, yet vengeance suffereth not to live.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And he shook off the beast into the fire, and felt no harm.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Howbeit they looked when he should have swollen, or fallen down dead suddenly: but after they had looked a great while, and saw no harm come to him, they changed their minds, and said that he was a god.

Author: Luke
Sentence: In the same quarters were possessions of the chief man of the island, whose name was Publius; who received us, and lodged us three days courteously.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And it came to pass, that the father of Publius lay sick of a fever and of a bloody flux: to whom Paul entered in, and prayed, and laid his hands on him, and healed him.

Author: Luke
Sentence: So when this was done, others also, which had diseases in the island, came, and were healed:

Author: Luke
Sentence: Who also honoured us with many honours; and when we departed, they laded [us] with such things as were necessary.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And after three months we departed in a ship of Alexandria, which had wintered in the isle, whose sign was Castor and Pollux.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And landing at Syracuse, we tarried [there] three days.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And from thence we fetched a compass, and came to Rhegium: and after one day the south wind blew, and we came the next day to Puteoli:

Author: Luke
Sentence: Where we found brethren, and were desired to tarry with them seven days: and so we went toward Rome.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And from thence, when the brethren heard of us, they came to meet us as far as Appii forum, and The three taverns: whom when Paul saw, he thanked God, and took courage.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when we came to Rome, the centurion delivered the prisoners to the captain of the guard: but Paul was suffered to dwell by himself with a soldier that kept him.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And it came to pass, that after three days Paul called the chief of the Jews together: and when they were come together, he said unto them, Men [and] brethren, though I have committed nothing against the people, or customs of our fathers, yet was I delivered prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Who, when they had examined me, would have let [me] go, because there was no cause of death in me.

Author: Luke
Sentence: But when the Jews spake against [it], I was constrained to appeal unto Caesar; not that I had ought to accuse my nation of.

Author: Luke
Sentence: For this cause therefore have I called for you, to see [you], and to speak with [you]: because that for the hope of Israel I am bound with this chain.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And they said unto him, We neither received letters out of Judaea concerning thee, neither any of the brethren that came shewed or spake any harm of thee.

Author: Luke
Sentence: But we desire to hear of thee what thou thinkest: for as concerning this sect, we know that every where it is spoken against.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when they had appointed him a day, there came many to him into [his] lodging; to whom he expounded and testified the kingdom of God, persuading them concerning Jesus, both out of the law of Moses, and [out of] the prophets, from morning till evening.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And some believed the things which were spoken, and some believed not.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when they agreed not among themselves, they departed, after that Paul had spoken one word, Well spake the Holy Ghost by Esaias the prophet unto our fathers,

Author: Luke
Sentence: Saying, Go unto this people, and say, Hearing ye shall hear, and shall not understand; and seeing ye shall see, and not perceive:

Author: Luke
Sentence: For the heart of this people is waxed gross, and their ears are dull of hearing, and their eyes have they closed; lest they should see with [their] eyes, and hear with [their] ears, and understand with [their] heart, and should be converted, and I should heal them.

Author: Luke
Sentence: Be it known therefore unto you, that the salvation of God is sent unto the Gentiles, and [that] they will hear it.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And when he had said these words, the Jews departed, and had great reasoning among themselves.

Author: Luke
Sentence: And Paul dwelt two whole years in his own hired house, and received all that came in unto him,

Author: Luke
Sentence: Preaching the kingdom of God, and teaching those things which concern the Lord Jesus Christ, with all confidence, no man forbidding him.

Author: John
Sentence: And I heard another out of the altar say, Even so, Lord God Almighty, true and righteous [are] thy judgments.

Author: John
Sentence: And the fourth angel poured out his vial upon the sun; and power was given unto him to scorch men with fire.

Sentence: Wherein in time past ye walked according to the course of this world, according to the prince of the power of the air, the spirit that now worketh in the children of disobedience:

Author: Paul
Sentence: Among whom also we all had our conversation in times past in the lusts of our flesh, fulfilling the desires of the flesh and of the mind; and were by nature the children of wrath, even as others.

Author: Paul
Sentence: But God, who is rich in mercy, for his great love wherewith he loved us,

Author: Paul
Sentence: Even when we were dead in sins, hath quickened us together with Christ, (by grace ye are saved;)

Author: Paul
Sentence: And hath raised [us] up together, and made [us] sit together in heavenly [places] in Christ Jesus:

Author: Paul
Sentence: That in the ages to come he might shew the exceeding riches of his grace in [his] kindness toward us through Christ Jesus.

Author: Paul
Sentence: For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: [it is] the gift of God:

Author: Paul
Sentence: Not of works, lest any man should boast.

Author: Paul
Sentence: For we are his workmanship, created in Christ Jesus unto good works, which God hath before ordained that we should walk in them.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Wherefore remember, that ye [being] in time past Gentiles in the flesh, who are called Uncircumcision by that which is called the Circumcision in the flesh made by hands;

Author: Paul
Sentence: That at that time ye were without Christ, being aliens from the commonwealth of Israel, and strangers from the covenants of promise, having no hope, and without God in the world:

Author: Paul
Sentence: But now in Christ Jesus ye who sometimes were far off are made nigh by the blood of Christ.

Author: Paul
Sentence: For he is our peace, who hath made both one, and hath broken down the middle wall of partition [between us];

Author: Paul
Sentence: Having abolished in his flesh the enmity, [even] the law of commandments [contained] in ordinances; for to make in himself of twain one new man, [so] making peace;

Author: Paul
Sentence: And that he might reconcile both unto God in one body by the cross, having slain the enmity thereby:

Author: Paul
Sentence: And came and preached peace to you which were afar off, and to them that were nigh.

Author: Paul
Sentence: For through him we both have access by one Spirit unto the Father.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Now therefore ye are no more strangers and foreigners, but fellowcitizens with the saints, and of the household of God;

Author: Paul
Sentence: And are built upon the foundation of the apostles and prophets, Jesus Christ himself being the chief corner [stone];

Author: Paul
Sentence: In whom all the building fitly framed together groweth unto an holy temple in the Lord:

Author: Paul
Sentence: In whom ye also are builded together for an habitation of God through the Spirit.

Author: Paul
Sentence: For this cause I Paul, the prisoner of Jesus Christ for you Gentiles,

Author: Paul
Sentence: If ye have heard of the dispensation of the grace of God which is given me to you-ward:

Author: Paul
Sentence: How that by revelation he made known unto me the mystery; (as I wrote afore in few words,

Author: Paul
Sentence: Whereby, when ye read, ye may understand my knowledge in the mystery of Christ)

Author: Paul
Sentence: Which in other ages was not made known unto the sons of men, as it is now revealed unto his holy apostles and prophets by the Spirit;

Author: Paul
Sentence: That the Gentiles should be fellowheirs, and of the same body, and partakers of his promise in Christ by the gospel:

Author: Paul
Sentence: Whereof I was made a minister, according to the gift of the grace of God given unto me by the effectual working of his power.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Unto me, who am less than the least of all saints, is this grace given, that I should preach among the Gentiles the unsearchable riches of Christ;

Author: Paul
Sentence: And to make all [men] see what [is] the fellowship of the mystery, which from the beginning of the world hath been hid in God, who created all things by Jesus Christ:

Author: Paul
Sentence: To the intent that now unto the principalities and powers in heavenly [places] might be known by the church the manifold wisdom of God,

Author: Paul
Sentence: According to the eternal purpose which he purposed in Christ Jesus our Lord:

Author: Paul
Sentence: In whom we have boldness and access with confidence by the faith of him.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Wherefore I desire that ye faint not at my tribulations for you, which is your glory.

Author: Paul
Sentence: For this cause I bow my knees unto the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ,

Author: Paul
Sentence: Of whom the whole family in heaven and earth is named,

Author: Paul
Sentence: That he would grant you, according to the riches of his glory, to be strengthened with might by his Spirit in the inner man;

Author: Paul
Sentence: That Christ may dwell in your hearts by faith; that ye, being rooted and grounded in love,

Author: Paul
Sentence: May be able to comprehend with all saints what [is] the breadth, and length, and depth, and height;

Author: Paul
Sentence: And to know the love of Christ, which passeth knowledge, that ye might be filled with all the fulness of God.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Now unto him that is able to do exceeding abundantly above all that we ask or think, according to the power that worketh in us,

Author: Paul
Sentence: Unto him [be] glory in the church by Christ Jesus throughout all ages, world without end.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Amen.

Author: Paul
Sentence: I therefore, the prisoner of the Lord, beseech you that ye walk worthy of the vocation wherewith ye are called,

Author: Paul
Sentence: With all lowliness and meekness, with longsuffering, forbearing one another in love;

Author: Paul
Sentence: Endeavouring to keep the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace.

Author: Paul
Sentence: [There is] one body, and one Spirit, even as ye are called in one hope of your calling;

Author: Paul
Sentence: One Lord, one faith, one baptism,

Author: Paul
Sentence: One God and Father of all, who [is] above all, and through all, and in you all.

Author: Paul
Sentence: But unto every one of us is given grace according to the measure of the gift of Christ.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Wherefore he saith, When he ascended up on high, he led captivity captive, and gave gifts unto men.

Author: Paul
Sentence: (Now that he ascended, what is it but that he also descended first into the lower parts of the earth?

Author: Paul
Sentence: He that descended is the same also that ascended up far above all heavens, that he might fill all things.)

Author: Paul
Sentence: And he gave some, apostles; and some, prophets; and some, evangelists; and some, pastors and teachers;

Author: Paul
Sentence: For the perfecting of the saints, for the work of the ministry, for the edifying of the body of Christ:

Author: Paul
Sentence: Till we all come in the unity of the faith, and of the knowledge of the Son of God, unto a perfect man, unto the measure of the stature of the fulness of Christ:

Author: Paul
Sentence: That we [henceforth] be no more children, tossed to and fro, and carried about with every wind of doctrine, by the sleight of men, [and] cunning craftiness, whereby they lie in wait to deceive;

Author: Paul
Sentence: But speaking the truth in love, may grow up into him in all things, which is the head, [even] Christ:

Author: Paul
Sentence: From whom the whole body fitly joined together and compacted by that which every joint supplieth, according to the effectual working in the measure of every part, maketh increase of the body unto the edifying of itself in love.

Author: Paul
Sentence: This I say therefore, and testify in the Lord, that ye henceforth walk not as other Gentiles walk, in the vanity of their mind,

Author: Paul
Sentence: Having the understanding darkened, being alienated from the life of God through the ignorance that is in them, because of the blindness of their heart:

Author: Paul
Sentence: Who being past feeling have given themselves over unto lasciviousness, to work all uncleanness with greediness.

Author: Paul
Sentence: But ye have not so learned Christ;

Author: Paul
Sentence: If so be that ye have heard him, and have been taught by him, as the truth is in Jesus:

Author: Paul
Sentence: That ye put off concerning the former conversation the old man, which is corrupt according to the deceitful lusts;

Author: Paul
Sentence: And be renewed in the spirit of your mind;

Author: Paul
Sentence: And that ye put on the new man, which after God is created in righteousness and true holiness.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Wherefore putting away lying, speak every man truth with his neighbour: for we are members one of another.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Be ye angry, and sin not: let not the sun go down upon your wrath:

Author: Paul
Sentence: Neither give place to the devil.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Let him that stole steal no more: but rather let him labour, working with [his] hands the thing which is good, that he may have to give to him that needeth.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Let no corrupt communication proceed out of your mouth, but that which is good to the use of edifying, that it may minister grace unto the hearers.

Author: Paul
Sentence: And grieve not the holy Spirit of God, whereby ye are sealed unto the day of redemption.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Let all bitterness, and wrath, and anger, and clamour, and evil speaking, be put away from you, with all malice:

Author: Paul
Sentence: And be ye kind one to another, tenderhearted, forgiving one another, even as God for Christ’s sake hath forgiven you.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Be ye therefore followers of God, as dear children;

Author: Paul
Sentence: And walk in love, as Christ also hath loved us, and hath given himself for us an offering and a sacrifice to God for a sweetsmelling savour.

Author: Paul
Sentence: But fornication, and all uncleanness, or covetousness, let it not be once named among you, as becometh saints;

Author: Paul
Sentence: Neither filthiness, nor foolish talking, nor jesting, which are not convenient: but rather giving of thanks.

Author: Paul
Sentence: For this ye know, that no whoremonger, nor unclean person, nor covetous man, who is an idolater, hath any inheritance in the kingdom of Christ and of God.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Let no man deceive you with vain words: for because of these things cometh the wrath of God upon the children of disobedience.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Be not ye therefore partakers with them.

Author: Paul
Sentence: For ye were sometimes darkness, but now [are ye] light in the Lord: walk as children of light:

Author: Paul
Sentence: (For the fruit of the Spirit [is] in all goodness and righteousness and truth;)

Author: Paul
Sentence: Proving what is acceptable unto the Lord.

Author: Paul
Sentence: And have no fellowship with the unfruitful works of darkness, but rather reprove [them].

Author: Paul
Sentence: For it is a shame even to speak of those things which are done of them in secret.

Author: Paul
Sentence: But all things that are reproved are made manifest by the light: for whatsoever doth make manifest is light.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Wherefore he saith, Awake thou that sleepest, and arise from the dead, and Christ shall give thee light.

Author: Paul
Sentence: See then that ye walk circumspectly, not as fools, but as wise,

Author: Paul
Sentence: Redeeming the time, because the days are evil.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Wherefore be ye not unwise, but understanding what the will of the Lord [is].

Author: Paul
Sentence: And be not drunk with wine, wherein is excess; but be filled with the Spirit;

Author: Paul
Sentence: Speaking to yourselves in psalms and hymns and spiritual songs, singing and making melody in your heart to the Lord;

Author: Paul
Sentence: Giving thanks always for all things unto God and the Father in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ;

Author: Paul
Sentence: Submitting yourselves one to another in the fear of God.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Wives, submit yourselves unto your own husbands, as unto the Lord.

Author: Paul
Sentence: For the husband is the head of the wife, even as Christ is the head of the church: and he is the saviour of the body.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Therefore as the church is subject unto Christ, so [let] the wives [be] to their own husbands in every thing.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Husbands, love your wives, even as Christ also loved the church, and gave himself for it;

Author: Paul
Sentence: That he might sanctify and cleanse it with the washing of water by the word,

Author: Paul
Sentence: That he might present it to himself a glorious church, not having spot, or wrinkle, or any such thing; but that it should be holy and without blemish.

Author: Paul
Sentence: So ought men to love their wives as their own bodies.

Author: Paul
Sentence: He that loveth his wife loveth himself.

Author: Paul
Sentence: For no man ever yet hated his own flesh; but nourisheth and cherisheth it, even as the Lord the church:

Author: Paul
Sentence: For we are members of his body, of his flesh, and of his bones.

Author: Paul
Sentence: For this cause shall a man leave his father and mother, and shall be joined unto his wife, and they two shall be one flesh.

Author: Paul
Sentence: This is a great mystery: but I speak concerning Christ and the church.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Nevertheless let every one of you in particular so love his wife even as himself; and the wife [see] that she reverence [her] husband.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Children, obey your parents in the Lord: for this is right.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Honour thy father and mother; (which is the first commandment with promise;)

Author: Paul
Sentence: That it may be well with thee, and thou mayest live long on the earth.

Author: Paul
Sentence: And, ye fathers, provoke not your children to wrath: but bring them up in the nurture and admonition of the Lord.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Servants, be obedient to them that are [your] masters according to the flesh, with fear and trembling, in singleness of your heart, as unto Christ;

Author: Paul
Sentence: Not with eyeservice, as menpleasers; but as the servants of Christ, doing the will of God from the heart;

Author: Paul
Sentence: With good will doing service, as to the Lord, and not to men:

Author: Paul
Sentence: Knowing that whatsoever good thing any man doeth, the same shall he receive of the Lord, whether [he be] bond or free.

Author: Paul
Sentence: And, ye masters, do the same things unto them, forbearing threatening: knowing that your Master also is in heaven; neither is there respect of persons with him.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Finally, my brethren, be strong in the Lord, and in the power of his might.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Put on the whole armour of God, that ye may be able to stand against the wiles of the devil.

Author: Paul
Sentence: For we wrestle not against flesh and blood, but against principalities, against powers, against the rulers of the darkness of this world, against spiritual wickedness in high [places].

Author: Paul
Sentence: Wherefore take unto you the whole armour of God, that ye may be able to withstand in the evil day, and having done all, to stand.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Stand therefore, having your loins girt about with truth, and having on the breastplate of righteousness;

Author: Paul
Sentence: And your feet shod with the preparation of the gospel of peace;

Author: Paul
Sentence: Above all, taking the shield of faith, wherewith ye shall be able to quench all the fiery darts of the wicked.

Author: Paul
Sentence: And take the helmet of salvation, and the sword of the Spirit, which is the word of God:

Author: Paul
Sentence: Praying always with all prayer and supplication in the Spirit, and watching thereunto with all perseverance and supplication for all saints;

Author: Paul
Sentence: And for me, that utterance may be given unto me, that I may open my mouth boldly, to make known the mystery of the gospel,

Author: Paul
Sentence: For which I am an ambassador in bonds: that therein I may speak boldly, as I ought to speak.

Author: Paul
Sentence: But that ye also may know my affairs, [and] how I do, Tychicus, a beloved brother and faithful minister in the Lord, shall make known to you all things:

Author: Paul
Sentence: Whom I have sent unto you for the same purpose, that ye might know our affairs, and [that] he might comfort your hearts.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Peace [be] to the brethren, and love with faith, from God the Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Grace [be] with all them that love our Lord Jesus Christ in sincerity.

Author: Paul
Sentence: Amen.

Author: Peter
Sentence: Knowing this first, that there shall come in the last days scoffers, walking after their own lusts,

Author: Peter
Sentence: And saying, Where is the promise of his coming?

Author: Peter
Sentence: for since the fathers fell asleep, all things continue as [they were] from the beginning of the creation.

Author: Peter
Sentence: For this they willingly are ignorant of, that by the word of God the heavens were of old, and the earth standing out of the water and in the water:

Author: Peter
Sentence: Whereby the world that then was, being overflowed with water, perished:

Author: Peter
Sentence: But the heavens and the earth, which are now, by the same word are kept in store, reserved unto fire against the day of judgment and perdition of ungodly men.

Author: Peter
Sentence: But, beloved, be not ignorant of this one thing, that one day [is] with the Lord as a thousand years, and a thousand years as one day.

Author: Peter
Sentence: The Lord is not slack concerning his promise, as some men count slackness; but is longsuffering to us-ward, not willing that any should perish, but that all should come to repentance.

Author: Peter
Sentence: But the day of the Lord will come as a thief in the night; in the which the heavens shall pass away with a great noise, and the elements shall melt with fervent heat, the earth also and the works that are therein shall be burned up.

Author: Peter
Sentence: [Seeing] then [that] all these things shall be dissolved, what manner [of persons] ought ye to be in [all] holy conversation and godliness,

Author: Peter
Sentence: Looking for and hasting unto the coming of the day of God, wherein the heavens being on fire shall be dissolved, and the elements shall melt with fervent heat?

Author: Peter
Sentence: Nevertheless we, according to his promise, look for new heavens and a new earth, wherein dwelleth righteousness.

Author: Peter
Sentence: Wherefore, beloved, seeing that ye look for such things, be diligent that ye may be found of him in peace, without spot, and blameless.

Author: Peter
Sentence: And account [that] the longsuffering of our Lord [is] salvation; even as our beloved brother Paul also according to the wisdom given unto him hath written unto you;

Author: Peter
Sentence: As also in all [his] epistles, speaking in them of these things; in which are some things hard to be understood, which they that are unlearned and unstable wrest, as [they do] also the other scriptures, unto their own destruction.

Author: Peter
Sentence: Ye therefore, beloved, seeing ye know [these things] before, beware lest ye also, being led away with the error of the wicked, fall from your own stedfastness.

Author: Peter
Sentence: But grow in grace, and [in] the knowledge of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ.

Author: Peter
Sentence: To him [be] glory both now and for ever.

Author: Peter
Sentence: Amen.

Author: James
Sentence: But above all things, my brethren, swear not, neither by heaven, neither by the earth, neither by any other oath: but let your yea be yea; and [your] nay, nay; lest ye fall into condemnation.

Author: James
Sentence: Is any among you afflicted?

Author: James
Sentence: let him pray.

Author: James
Sentence: Is any merry?

Author: James
Sentence: let him sing psalms.

Author: James
Sentence: Is any sick among you?

Author: James
Sentence: let him call for the elders of the church; and let them pray over him, anointing him with oil in the name of the Lord:

Author: James
Sentence: And the prayer of faith shall save the sick, and the Lord shall raise him up; and if he have committed sins, they shall be forgiven him.

Author: James
Sentence: Confess [your] faults one to another, and pray one for another, that ye may be healed.

Author: James
Sentence: The effectual fervent prayer of a righteous man availeth much.

Author: James
Sentence: Elias was a man subject to like passions as we are, and he prayed earnestly that it might not rain: and it rained not on the earth by the space of three years and six months.

Author: James
Sentence: And he prayed again, and the heaven gave rain, and the earth brought forth her fruit.

Author: James
Sentence: Brethren, if any of you do err from the truth, and one convert him;

Author: James
Sentence: Let him know, that he which converteth the sinner from the error of his way shall save a soul from death, and shall hide a multitude of sins.

Author: Jude
Sentence: Now unto him that is able to keep you from falling, and to present [you] faultless before the presence of his glory with exceeding joy,

Author: Jude
Sentence: To the only wise God our Saviour, [be] glory and majesty, dominion and power, both now and ever.

Author: Jude
Sentence: Amen.
